thread.title: Paramedics honored for saving man after allergic reaction
thread.title_full: Paramedics honored for saving man after allergic reaction - Sun Sentinel

author: Marci Shatzman
title: Paramedics honored for saving man after allergic reaction
text:
John Stredwick knew if he got another bug bite it might be his last.
So when the highly allergic 76-year-old passed out in the bathroom after walking his dog George, his wife Grace called 911.
The call came into Fire Station 51 and three paramedics were at the Lakes of Boca Barwood in no time. "He was bright red and short of breath," said Lt. Cathy Murray. "That's the most severe reaction I've seen."
"I'm a gardener and the first time was 16 years ago with a yellow jacket," John Stredwick said about his first allergic reaction.
This time, he speculated a spider may have been hiding in his shoe, and added he has stints in his heart and a pacemaker.
When the ambulance pulled into the driveway at West Boca Medical Center's emergency room, the red bug bites on his leg were gone, but was still unconscious.
Caption Going inside the hive for a honey harvest Broward County Beekeeper’s Association President Dan Novak takes us with him as he harvests honey from his backyard bee hives. 
Broward County Beekeeper’s Association President Dan Novak takes us with him as he harvests honey from his backyard bee hives. 
Caption Watch these wiener dogs competing for the title of fastest dachshund More than 90 wiener dogs raced each other during the 5th Dachstoberfest in West Palm Beach. Puppies, seniors and adults competed for the title of "Fastest Dachshund."
More than 90 wiener dogs raced each other during the 5th Dachstoberfest in West Palm Beach. Puppies, seniors and adults competed for the title of "Fastest Dachshund."
"The first thing I knew, I was in intensive care," he said.
That was over Thanksgiving, and on Feb. 7, the grateful Stredwicks were reunited with the paramedics that saved his life at the medical center's Call of the Quarter event to honor the team.
"This started with an insect bite that caused an anaphylactic reaction," said hospital CEO Mitch Feldman. He presented the paramedics with a plaque and the Stredwicks went up to hug them, trailed by George the dog.
"Thank you for your prompt and professional service," John Stredwick told the trio after the presentation. "I had the best nursing attention. I can't speak too highly of my care. It was like being in the Ritz."
Margaret Neddo, director of ER Services, stood in for the medical team.
"We don't get to see the outcome," paramedic Mark Roloff said afterward.
"The typical response is doughnuts," brought to the firehouse at State Road 7 and Judge Winikoff Road, said paramedic Matthew Oberman.
"This is our job and we love it, but to see how he's doing is great," Murray said.
